title: SPARQL Feature Detection

author: Robert D. Blair, School of Electronics and Computer Science, University of Southampton

segmentation: Good morning everybody.
Hear me OK. Good right?
So I'd like to welcome you to the presentation by Coop Research.
This is a presentation about endpoint functionality and endpoint selection.
The team members are Muhammad's Fabian Chi, myself, Roberts and Serge are tutors are Maribel and Aiden.
OK so.

Going to be looking at endpoint functionality and how this can affect selection of endpoints, so our outline is we're going to talk about the motivation, the objectives, what our solution was, and then we're going to discuss a scenario and give a demo of what we produced next.

Please, So what is our problem?
How does a developer note which endpoints to use?
Which endpoint is the most suitable for the functionality that they require for the particular domain or data set we have?
Sparkle standards so we have for instance, so queries, property, paths, bindings, etc.
But even though these sparkle standards, they are not enforceable, these are voluntarily adopted.
We also have best practice so we can have keyword search, but there's also a variety of different syntax.
So the problem is at the base of it.
We have a lack of compliance, like a full compliance to the sparkle standards, and the developer can end up wasting time.
What are objectives?
Develop a solution so that the developer can use the most suitable endpoint.
Doesn't waste time.
Our solution must produce results which are accessible to humans, so instant feedback very easily understand what's available.
It's not available.
Also, our results are going to be available in machine readable formats, RDF outputs and this is for later consumption analysis.
You can have persisted records so that you can do comparisons overtime.
First thing we want to do is to incorporate or to promote the idea of community by and and utilizing Community expertise.
What was our solution?
We're going to create checks for the modern sparkle features.
We want these checks to be conducted automatically beyond the end.
User does not have to individually or manually input these checks.
Output color coded function matrix very easily understood and RDF output.
Utilizing aspects of void.
Again, this community enriched solutions.
We if we forget if we get the community to buy into this then solutions are much more likely to be applicable and to be further developed.
Next slide, please.
So to test this, to test our solution, we decide well what's this scenario a designer wishes to query linked open data.
This owner developer comes up with a preliminary set of endpoints have gone to, for instance, data hub means they've looked into domain said OK, this set of endpoints looks interesting.
Let's check these.
What's the application going to do is going to identify the features of each endpoint so very quickly so that the developing to decide which is the most suitable for themselves.
Now we're coming to our demo, which is the application which we call feature.
Here you can see very simple dashboard which is what the developer would see and it looks fairly straightforward.
We have an endpoint input, we have a series with running developed application.
You have a series of endpoints here which have already been interrogated and you can see we have a series of functionality's along the top there very straightforward functionality can be increased.
We increase the range of functionality you would have color coding.

They can submit that.

We've been looking at compliance.
Compared to endpoint functionality.
We've looked at.
Suggesting and helping contributed the idea of selecting a suitable endpoints.

From this we can go on to our.
Look so with our future work be.
Well.
When there's enough data, when there's enough interrogation that is being conducted, we can publish our benchmark vocabulary saying this is how we tested all of the endpoints.
This is how we came up with our data.

Promote, encourage the idea of this Community solution rating system so when alternatives have been presented, can we actually ask the community to rate which is the best alternative which is most suitable?
The third thing we want to look at is something which we haven't mentioned before, but the idea is you've got many endpoints much different functionality.
But another problem is that there's different syntax used by different endpoint providers.
We'd like to create or we would envisage creating a translation layer so the end user puts in one keyword.
And our translation layer will take that query and interrogate all the different endpoints based upon the syntax which those endpoints have.
So therefore it's a translation layer, three piece of work, and.
Ladies and gentlemen, our lab.
